column1: Hurricane Harvey: Stars react, donate money in support of relief efforts
column3: Celebrity News Hurricane Harvey: Stars react, donate money support relief efforts Fox News Facebook Twitter Print Email close Celebrities send support Hurricane Harvey victims Fox411: Kevin Hart, JJ Watt Chip Joanna Gaines celebrities sending support people Houston parts Texas affected Hurricane Harvey large charitable donations Celebrities sending support people Houston parts Texas affected Hurricane Harvey. The weekend storm brought "unprecedented" flooding Houston making landfall Texas Category 4 hurricane Friday. On Monday, Houston nearby towns received 24 inches rainfall, trapping residents homes forcing roofs rescuers work around clock bring shelter. HURRICANE HARVEY VICTIMS: HERE IS WHAT YOU CAN DO TO HELP More stars opened wallets help Texas storm, including Kardashian family, pledged $500,000, country singer Chris Young, pledged $100,000. Kevin Hart, challenged celebrities donate, increased contribution amount $50,000. Chris Brown gave $100,000. Beyonce, Houston native, announced Tuesday working charity assist affected flooding hometown. "My heart goes hometown, Houston, I remain constant prayer affected," said statement Houston Chronicle. Texas native Miranda Lambert tweeted heartbroken news, meanwhile, celebrities took social media express thoughts prayers affected storm. Mr. McNair #Texans pledging $1 million dollars United Way Greater Houston Flood Relief Fund. #HoustonStrong pic.twitter.com/emzPzGdnr7— Houston Texans (@HoustonTexans) August 28, 2017 Houston praying you! My mom, sisters & I donating $500,000 @redcross @salvationarmyus today #HoustonStrong— Kim Kardashian West (@KimKardashian) August 29, 2017 A special song Houston last night's show. R42https://t.co/3J5e6gvdtm— Coldplay (@coldplay) August 29, 2017 Click link Bio & help help Houston well cities affected Hurricane Harvey....I able track money make sure used properly. Keep head Houston & keep faith. I love & prayers you!!!! Click link Bio....I calling celebs daily. You also celebrity donate....Any everybody click link help out!!!! CLICK THE LINK IN MY BIO A post shared Kevin Hart (@kevinhart4real) Aug 28, 2017 3:37pm PDT Texas hit hard Hurricane Harvey. I also want thank men women service volunteers courageous efforts help people need. I encourage everyone assist people Texas knowing whatever effort make help go long way. column1: José Andrés asks Trump to end legal battle, donate money to veterans
column3:
var articleInfo = { vcmId: "ada41cd9-7d86-45d9-9969-dcac27a5b3bd", url: "http://www.foxnews.com/food-drink/2016/12/14/jos-andr-s-asks-trump-to-end-legal-battle-donate-money-to-veterans.html", pubDate:"2016-12-14", myTopChannelName:"food-drink", summary:"

The chef tweeted president-elect Tuesday.<\/p>", baynoteOrOutbrain:"outbrain", commenting: "true", partnerInfo: {"partner": {"source": "","info": []}} }; var disqus_identifier = "ada41cd9-7d86-45d9-9969-dcac27a5b3bd"; var disqus_category_id = ""; var disqus_developer = 1; Home Restaurants Fast Food Celebrity Chefs Extreme Foods Food Trends Holiday Celebrity Chefs José Andrés asks Trump end legal battle, donate money veterans Published December 14, 2016 Fox News Facebook0 Twitter0 livefyre Email Print Just two weeks inauguration Washington, D.C., Donald Trump set deposed ongoing legal battle chef José Andrés. The Spanish-born chef originally slated open restaurant Trump International Hotel nation’s capital, pulled project hotel's opening following controversial comments made president-elect Mexican immigrants campaign trail. In August 2015, Trump sued Andres' company ThinkFood Group breach contract, seeking $10 million. The chef since countersued. On Tuesday, Andrés proposed new idea, tweeting directly Trump seek amicable end ongoing squabble also good. "Can end lawsuits donate $ Veterans NGO celebrate?" chef tweeted. "Why keep litigating? Let's us win.." Mr. @realDonaldTrump end lawsuits donate $ Veterans NGO celebrate? Why keep litigating? Let's us win.. — José Andrés (@chefjoseandres) December 13, 2016 The tweet since liked 400 times. As Wednesday morning, Trump responded Andres. FAMED NEW YORK CITY SUSHI RESTAURANT NAKAZAWA JOINING TRUMP'S DC HOTEL In June, president-elect deposed similar lawsuit Food Network star Geoffrey Zakarian. The Armenian-American chef planned open restaurant, The National, Old Post Office building-turned-hotel nation's capital. Zakarian also pulled project citing Trump’s comments immigrants. The Associated Press contributed report. column1: Louisiana televangelist seeks donations for $54M private jet: report
column3: Evangelical Louisiana televangelist seeks donations $54M private jet: report By Bradford Betz | Fox News Facebook Twitter Flipboard Comments Print Email close Video Televangelist seeks donations $54M private jet Jesse Duplantis, Louisiana-based televangelist, asking followers donate money $54 million jet, "go anywhere world one stop." He’d airplane preaching gospel world. - Jesse Duplantis “I really believe Jesus physically earth today, wouldn’t riding donkey,” Duplantis says video, “He’d airplane preaching gospel world.” Duplantis’ video comes another televangelist, Kenneth Copeland Texas, purchased Gulfstream V jet $36 million. A 100-year-old veteran received $1,000 local group victimized home invasion plans donate cash charity, told FoxNews.com.<\/p>", baynoteOrOutbrain:"outbrain", commenting: "true", partnerInfo: {"partner": {"source": "","info": []}} }; var disqus_identifier = "a97c9445-241f-47bb-b373-5d872a2ac5c5"; var disqus_category_id = "464444"; var disqus_developer = 1; U.S. Home Crime Terrorism Economy Immigration Disasters Military Education Environment Personal Freedoms Regions Veterans 100-year-old vet plans donate money received group robbery By Joshua Rhett Miller Published July 21, 2014 Fox News Facebook0 Twitter0 livefyre Email Print James V. Sorrentino, Carson City, Nev., received hefty lump sum form oversized check members Western Nevada College’s Veterans Resource Center Friday, nearly two months two men forced way home looking safe May 25. (Courtesy: Western Nevada College Veterans Resource Center) A 100-year-old veteran "overwhelmed" paying forward fellow service members presented check $1,000 take sting home invasion two months ago, told FoxNews.com. James V. Sorrentino, Carson City, Nev., received hefty lump sum form oversized check members Western Nevada College’s Veterans Resource Center Friday, nearly two months two men forced way home looking safe May 25. “I overwhelmed,” Sorrentino told FoxNews.com group’s kindness. “But I really don’t need it, I’ll donate charity.” Sorrentino, World War II Army Air Corps Air Force veteran, said hadn’t decided exactly he’ll donate money, raised veterans group benefit poker run June. [pullquote] “I’m grateful,” continued. “[It] shows spirit group.” Timothy Galluzi said group “more thrilled” come Sorrentino’s aid learning incident. “Our efforts keeping motto ‘veterans helping veterans,’” Galluzi wrote email. “The smile face made months hard work event well worth it.” After ransacking Sorrentino’s home, contain safe, suspects fled wristwatch, pocketknife wallet containing $30. One suspects, Jordan Burkhart, pleaded guilty felony robbery charge person 60. The 24-year-old Wellington man faces 35 years prison he’s sentenced next month. The suspect, 27-year-old Robert Hernandez Carson City, tried plead guilty charge plea accepted, KRNV-TV reports. He’s expected appear another hearing week. Galluzi, meanwhile, told FoxNews.com Sorrentino “definitely surprised” saw oversized check Friday. “It community effort got brought attention I told guys happened, definitely wanted get involved,” Galluzi told FoxNews.com. “That huge smile face made worthwhile.” The Associated Press contributed report. column1: Allies use Trump assassination wish scandal to fundraise for Missouri Dem
column3: STATE AND LOCAL Allies use Trump assassination wish scandal fundraise Missouri Dem By Alex Pappas, Fox News Facebook Twitter Print Email Missouri state Sen. Maria Chappelle-Nadal speaks Senate floor Jefferson City, Mo. Chappelle-Nadal says posted deleted comment Facebook said hoped President Donald Trump's assassination. The Democratic Senator says mean posted Thursday, Aug. 17, 2017, frustrated president's reaction violence last weekend Charlottesville, Va (AP Photo/Jeff Roberson) Allies state senator Missouri fighting keep seat saying hopes President Trump assassinated set website encouraged people donate money embattled Democrat. But Fox News asked questions request donations, fundraising link disappeared site. State Sen. Maria Chappelle-Nadal told Fox News statement Wednesday appreciates “gesture show support” supporter set site. The “I stand Maria” website included link Chappelle-Nadal’s fundraising page ActBlue, online platform used Democrats raise money online. "An enthusiastic supporter started website - www.istandwithmaria.com - collect signatures support staying Missouri Senate,” Chappelle-Nadal said. “They added link Senate ActBlue, public. The page nice gesture show support." In subsequent statement, Chappelle-Nadal said asked fundraising link removed. "I requested supporter take ActBlue tab website," said. By Wednesday evening, fundraising button removed. The website includes petition supporters don’t think resign. The site attempts rationalize comments. “We know huge difference saying someone hopes Donald Trump assassinated someone calling assassination,” site says. Trouble started Chappelle-Nadal posting Facebook last week: “I hope Trump assassinated!” Chappelle-Nadal eventually deleted post, screenshot saved shared Twitter. MISSOURI SENATOR WHO URGED TRUMP ASSASSINATION BOOTED FROM COMMITTEES In interviews, Chapelle-Nadal said regrets words anger president. She blamed outburst president's response white supremacist violence Charlottesville. On Sunday, offered apology. “President Trump, I apologize family,” Chappelle-Nadal said. “I also apologize people Missouri. And I also apologize colleagues Missouri legislature mistake I made.” Top Missouri Democrats – including Sen. Claire McCaskill chairman Missouri Democratic Party – called Chapelle-Nadal resign. Meanwhile, Chapelle-Nadal stripped committee assignments Missouri's Republican governor lieutenant governor said move expel office doesn’t resign. But Chappelle-Nadal said won’t quit. “There way hell I’m resigning,” told KMOX Radio last week. The Spanish-born chef originally slated open restaurant Trump International Hotel nation’s capital, pulled project hotel's opening following controversial comments made president-elect Mexican immigrants campaign trail. In August 2015, Trump sued Andres' company ThinkFood Group breach contract, seeking $10 million. The chef since countersued. On Tuesday, Andrés proposed new idea, tweeting directly Trump seek amicable end ongoing squabble also good. "Can end lawsuits donate $ Veterans NGO celebrate?" chef tweeted. "Why keep litigating? Let's us win.." Mr. @realDonaldTrump end lawsuits donate $ Veterans NGO celebrate? Why keep litigating? Let's us win.. — José Andrés (@chefjoseandres) December 13, 2016 The tweet since liked 400 times. As Wednesday morning, Trump responded Andres. FAMED NEW YORK CITY SUSHI RESTAURANT NAKAZAWA JOINING TRUMP'S DC HOTEL In June, president-elect deposed similar lawsuit Food Network star Geoffrey Zakarian. The Armenian-American chef planned open restaurant, The National, Old Post Office building-turned-hotel nation's capital. Zakarian also pulled project citing Trump’s comments immigrants. Sorrentino, Carson City, Nev., received hefty lump sum form oversized check members Western Nevada College’s Veterans Resource Center Friday, nearly two months two men forced way home looking safe May 25. (Courtesy: Western Nevada College Veterans Resource Center) A 100-year-old veteran "overwhelmed" paying forward fellow service members presented check $1,000 take sting home invasion two months ago, told FoxNews.com. James V. Sorrentino, Carson City, Nev., received hefty lump sum form oversized check members Western Nevada College’s Veterans Resource Center Friday, nearly two months two men forced way home looking safe May 25. “I overwhelmed,” Sorrentino told FoxNews.com group’s kindness. “But I really don’t need it, I’ll donate charity.” Sorrentino, World War II Army Air Corps Air Force veteran, said hadn’t decided exactly he’ll donate money, raised veterans group benefit poker run June. [pullquote] “I’m grateful,” continued. “[It] shows spirit group.” Timothy Galluzi said group “more thrilled” come Sorrentino’s aid learning incident. “Our efforts keeping motto ‘veterans helping veterans,’” Galluzi wrote email. “The smile face made months hard work event well worth it.” After ransacking Sorrentino’s home, contain safe, suspects fled wristwatch, pocketknife wallet containing $30. One suspects, Jordan Burkhart, pleaded guilty felony robbery charge person 60. The 24-year-old Wellington man faces 35 years prison he’s sentenced next month. The suspect, 27-year-old Robert Hernandez Carson City, tried plead guilty charge plea accepted, KRNV-TV reports. He’s expected appear another hearing week. Galluzi, meanwhile, told FoxNews.com Sorrentino “definitely surprised” saw oversized check Friday. “It community effort got brought attention I told guys happened, definitely wanted get involved,” Galluzi told FoxNews.com. “That huge smile face made worthwhile.” The Associated Press contributed report. column1: Allies use Trump assassination wish scandal to fundraise for Missouri Dem
column3: STATE AND LOCAL Allies use Trump assassination wish scandal fundraise Missouri Dem By Alex Pappas, Fox News Facebook Twitter Print Email Missouri state Sen. Maria Chappelle-Nadal speaks Senate floor Jefferson City, Mo. Chappelle-Nadal says posted deleted comment Facebook said hoped President Donald Trump's assassination. The Democratic Senator says mean posted Thursday, Aug. 17, 2017, frustrated president's reaction violence last weekend Charlottesville, Va (AP Photo/Jeff Roberson) Allies state senator Missouri fighting keep seat saying hopes President Trump assassinated set website encouraged people donate money embattled Democrat. But Fox News asked questions request donations, fundraising link disappeared site. State Sen. Maria Chappelle-Nadal told Fox News statement Wednesday appreciates “gesture show support” supporter set site. The “I stand Maria” website included link Chappelle-Nadal’s fundraising page ActBlue, online platform used Democrats raise money online. "An enthusiastic supporter started website - www.istandwithmaria.com - collect signatures support staying Missouri Senate,” Chappelle-Nadal said. “They added link Senate ActBlue, public. The page nice gesture show support." In subsequent statement, Chappelle-Nadal said asked fundraising link removed. "I requested supporter take ActBlue tab website," said. By Wednesday evening, fundraising button removed. The website includes petition supporters don’t think resign. The site attempts rationalize comments. “We know huge difference saying someone hopes Donald Trump assassinated someone calling assassination,” site says. Trouble started Chappelle-Nadal posting Facebook last week: “I hope Trump assassinated!” Chappelle-Nadal eventually deleted post, screenshot saved shared Twitter. MISSOURI SENATOR WHO URGED TRUMP ASSASSINATION BOOTED FROM COMMITTEES In interviews, Chapelle-Nadal said regrets words anger president. She blamed outburst president's response white supremacist violence Charlottesville. On Sunday, offered apology. “President Trump, I apologize family,” Chappelle-Nadal said. “I also apologize people Missouri. And I also apologize colleagues Missouri legislature mistake I made.” Top Missouri Democrats – including Sen. Claire McCaskill chairman Missouri Democratic Party – called Chapelle-Nadal resign. Meanwhile, Chapelle-Nadal stripped committee assignments Missouri's Republican governor lieutenant governor said move expel office doesn’t resign. But Chappelle-Nadal said won’t quit. “There way hell I’m resigning,” told KMOX Radio last week.
